items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Title V, Section 58301, the Board of Trustees shall hold a public hearing on the proposed budget on or before the 15th day of September.
	 
The District is required to make available the proposed budget for public inspection at least three days prior. Notification of date and location on the proposed budget shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the District. Accordingly, notice was posted in the San Jose Mercury News on Saturday, August 22, 2015, and the proposed budget was made available to the public for inspection on Thursday, September 3, 2015.
	 
This item is intended to identify the place on the agenda where the public may appear and comment on the proposed budget or any item in the budget.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $86,000 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of July 10, 2015 through August 9, 2015 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
In 2013, the state’s AB86-mandated process initiated the formation of a regional consortium (the South Bay Consortium for Adult Education - SBCAE) and tasked the consortium with creating a regional plan to transform services provided to adult learners.  The regional plan must ensure a successful transition of adult learners into either college or into employment. With input from all seven participating districts, as well as approximately 30 community organizations, SBCAE developed a three year plan to address services gaps and to align and expand adult education services within the region.  This regionally supported plan was submitted to the state in March 2015. The submitted plan has been accepted.
In June 2015, AB104 introduced an Adult Education Block Grant (AEBG) of dedicated adult education funding.  Included in the AEBG is “maintenance of effort” funding that will go directly to K-12 districts. AEBG funding over and above the maintenance of effort in the 2015-2016 fiscal year, and all funding in years following must be aligned to regional plans previously submitted to the state.  AB104 language requires  all consortium members to participate in implementation decisions, and calls for publicly-noticed meetings of formal representatives of each member district, approved by each member’s governance board.  Attached is the SBCAE Charter, ready for submission to the State. 
This board action formalizes the continuation of  Vice Chancellor Coen and Dean Vujjeni to represent the SJECCD interests in the SBCAE Consortium.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees formalize the continuation of Vice Chancellor Carol Coen and Dean Kishan Vujjeni as SJECCD representatives to the SBCAE Steering Committee.
items.item_text: Formalization of SJECCD's representation in the South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE)
items.item_text_raw: 7. Formalization of SJECCD's representation in the South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE)

items.item_details:
This Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) established a cooperative and mutually beneficial relationship between Evergreen Valley College (EVC) and West Valley College (WVC).  The colleges coordinate and implement the Career Pathways in the Water Industry for the Bay Area Region.  
	 
The basis of this MOU is a commitment to foster and continue to improve Career Pathways in the Water Industry in the Bay Region, through open communication and collaboration at strategic and operational levels to comply with the Career Pathway Grant requirements.
	 
EVC coordinates and provides access to the following opportunities:
	 
Building articulation agreements for water related courses.
Implementing certificate program on Waste Water Treatment operator technician pathways.
Working with industry and high school partners to verify a certificate program and supporting building block activities/curriculum.
Deploying verified, existing curriculum into existing high school courses as lessons and modules in existing courses, including career readiness, financial literacy, and basic math and English skills into water training curriculum.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Career Pathways Trust Memoraundum of Understanding between Evergreen Valley College and West Valley College.
items.item_text: Career Pathways Trust Memorandum of Understanding between Evergreen Valley College and West Valley College
items.item_text_raw: 8. Career Pathways Trust Memorandum of Understanding between Evergreen Valley College and West Valley College

items.item_details:
Southeast Asian American Student Excellence (SEAASE) is a project to recruit, prepare, and guide more Southeast Asian American (SEAA) students to seize the opportunity to enroll at EVC and complete major steps toward their personal goals for academic excellence.  The special focus of the project is the new Vietnamese and other SEAA students who enroll at EVC each year. This target population, as a group, needs reinforcement in making the transition to college, setting assertive careers goals, expanding critical thinking and leadership skills and developing fluency in business English.  
	 
Much of the needed support for SEAA students arises from differences between their cultural heritage and the dominant “American” culture.  “Seizing” something, for example, would be standard in the dominant US culture, but not in a culture that values respect and avoids unnecessary confrontation.  Each participant in Project SEAASE will learn how to understand these culture differences and how to confront their personal decisions regarding their place in this spectrum.   
	 
Project SEAASE will increase the capacity of EVC to serve the range of needs of SEAA students and demonstrate that capacity by achieving higher results for additional new SEAA students.  To accomplish this, a series of services will implement the single activity of the Project: Infusing culturally appropriate information and examples into the recruiting, preparation and teaching of SEAA students at EVC.  These new or expanded services include: outreach and support for initial enrollment, introductory summer programs, more student engagement, new teaching modules, advanced teaching of English skills, and intrusive career coaching.  
	 
A grant of $1,426,230 was awarded under the US Dept. of Education program to 
Strengthen Asian American, Native American and Pacific Islander-Serving Institutions
	 
AWARD PERIODS
PERFORMANCE PERIOD 10/01/2015 - 09/30/2020
	 
BUDGET PERIOD DATE AMOUNT
Year 1 10/01/2015 - 09/30/2016 $281,000.00
Year 2 10/01/2016 - 09/30/2017 $284,710.00
Year 3 10/01/2017 - 09/30/2018 $279,680.00
Year 4 10/01/2018 - 09/30/2019 $288,170.00
Year 5 10/01/2019 - 09/30/2020 $292,670.00

items.item_details: The City of San Jose (work2future) has included Workforce Institute in its WIA/WIOA Cohort Training Pool and has awarded a NTE contract of $1,170,478 to each of its service providers. Funds will be allocated as needed to select providers to provide cohort based educational instruction to WIA/WIOA eligible clients looking for a career change or to upgrade their skills to increase employability. This contract covers 2015-2016 fiscal year and includes workshops for Job Readiness and Job/Entrepreneurial training.  Workforce Institute anticipates realizing $125,000 from this Training Contract Pool in 2015-2016.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2015-2016 WIA/WIOA Cohort Training Pool Contract.

items.item_details:
The City of San Jose (work2future) has included Workforce Institute in its Youth Career Technical Training provider pool and has awarded a NTE contract of $172,627 to each of the training providers in the pool.  As WIA /WIOA clients select the training of their choice, the contract dollars will be allocated to the various providers.  Training will be cohort-based educational instruction to eligible clients looking for a career change/upgrading their skills to increase their employability.
 
Workforce Institute anticipates realizing $70,000 from this Youth Career Technical Training Contract Pool in 2015-2016.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2015–2016 WIA/WIOA work2future Youth Career Technical Training Contract
items.item_text: Workforce Institute – 2015-2016 WIA/WIOA work2future Youth Career Technical Training Contract
items.item_text_raw: 11. Workforce Institute – 2015-2016 WIA/WIOA work2future Youth Career Technical Training Contract

items.item_details:
Since 2000, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose (work2future) to provide job readiness workshops to Santa Clara County job seekers.  Workforce Institute has delivered those workshops at multiple locations in Campbell, Gilroy, and San Jose in an effort to equip them with the skills they need to market themselves.  
	 
For program year 2015-2016, work2future has included Workforce Institute in its WIA/WIOA Workshop Provider List and has awarded a NTE contract pool of $1,170,478 to each of its service providers to deliver instructor led workshops based upon the Department of Labor, Education, and Training Administration competency models. Actual revenue earned through the WIA/WIOA Workshop Provider List is predicated on clients choosing Workforce Institute courses from a menu of workshops offered via multiple providers. 
	 
Workforce Institute anticipates realizing $200,00 from the WIA/WIOA Workshops Contract Pool in 2015-2016.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2015-2016 WIA/WIOA Workshop Contract.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute – WIA/WIOA work2future Workshop Contract
items.item_text_raw: 12. Workforce Institute – WIA/WIOA work2future Workshop Contract

items.item_details:
On June 9, 2015 the SJECCD Board of Trustees accepted the California Career Pathways Trust (CCPT) grant award for the regional Silicon Valley Engineering Tech Pathways (SVETP) project in the amount of $13,173,153, for the four year term: 3 years grant funded: July 1, 2015 – June 30, 2018 and 1 year sustainable: July 1, 2018 – June 30, 2019.
	 
The San Jose Evergreen Community College District, through Workforce Institute, was awarded the regional collaborative grant to create and expand Science Technology Engineering Math (STEM) in the Silicon Valley’s K12 through community colleges.  The purpose of the regional collaboration is to engage students’ middle school through college.  Beginning in middle school students receive career awareness, continuing through high school with career preparation, moving to community college for accelerated, contextual STEM foundation skills and career pathway certificates and work- based-learning.  SVETP focuses on three high-demand, high-wage industry sectors: Information and Communications Technology (ICT), Engineering and Advanced Manufacturing. 
	 
The attached MOU enables the SVETP collaboration of 28 partners (9 community colleges, 6 unified school districts, 2 alternative/charter schools, 3 California State Universities, 3 workforce investment  boards, 2 workforce intermediaries, 2 professional development providers and the external evaluator) to begin implementation of CCPT grant deliverables.  The MOU, approved as to form by SJECCD Contracts and Risk Management, includes all the California Department of Education required elements and will be executed by the authorized agent of each partner institution.  The SVETP budget allocation provides partners with the following funding for the term of July 1, 2015 – June 30, 2019:
	 
Community Colleges:
Evergreen Valley College                              $425,000
Foothill College                                                360,000
Las Positas                                                      400,000
Mission College                                               360,000
Monterey Peninsula College                            400,000
Ohlone College                                                 570,000
San Jose City College                                      425,000
Skyline College                                                 400,000
West Valley College                                         360,000
School Districts and Alternative/Charter Schools:
Campbell Union HSD                                      118,500
East Site Union HSD                                       377,100
Fremont Union HSD                                        159,000
MetroED                                                          177,000
Milpitas USD                                                   145,500
Santa Clara USD                                             222,400
Stride Center                                                   160,000
Alpha Public School                                        130,000
California State Universities:
CSU – East Bay                                               105,000
San Francisco State                                         105,000
San Jose State                                                 165,000
Workforce Investment Boards:
Alameda WIB                                                     40,000
NOVA                                                                 35,000
Work2Future                                                      35,000
Workforce Intermediaries                                           
Growth Sector                                              2,465,000
Transmosis                                                     110,000
Other:
TED-Ed, Professional Development              200,000
UCLA-HERI, Evaluator                                  125,000
Lawrence Livermore National Labs               400,000
        (STEM Bootcamps and Mobile Learning Lab)
	 
Scope of Work:
San Jose Evergreen CCD: The SJECCD portion of the grant will be $5,548,653; Workforce Institute will receive $4,032,159.73 for grants management, student intern stipends, marketing, project administration and oversight (this includes Indirect), Evergreen Valley and San Jose City  Colleges receive $425,000 each for STEM Core and 6 career pathways. The District Office will receive $166,493.27 for fiscal, budget and administrative integration.
	 
Community Colleges:  Each community college agrees to collaborate to meet the SVETP regional career pathways plan to implement 15 Information and Communications Technology pathways, 10 Engineering Technology pathways, and 6 Advanced Manufacturing pathways that will serve over 3460 students with exposure to hands-on work-based learning activities, and has a goal to assist over 500 students receive a state approve CTE Certificate.
	 
K-12 Districts / Alternative / Charter Schools:  In the SVETP region the number of K-12 students exposed to, exploring or enrolled in the STEM foundation related career pathways program will be approximately 7200 between  2015-2019.  Local USDs will collect data on the number of students enrolled in their career academies and other pathways, and will refine this data collection so that it aligns with the shared definition of "career pathway programs".
	 
California State Universities:  San Jose State, San Francisco State and CSU-East Bay are all joining the SVETP partnership to assist with marketing outreach, to employ Math Science Teaching Initiative (MSTI) students to assume the Student Support Specialist roles in sustainability outlier years, for their work experience stipend, and to provide professional development to STEM faculty and teachers. 
	 
Workforce Investment Boards (becoming Workforce Development Boards):  The SVETP region 3 WIBS, Alameda WIB, Nova and Work2Future, and all have experience working with the workforce intermediaries to link WIA/WIOA eligible students with WIOA funded work-experience opportunities in high-growth, high- demand, high-wage career areas that respond to the growing need for youth 16-24 to have industry recognized career skills and certification. 
	 
Workforce Intermediaries:  Growth Sector is the primary workforce intermediary, and will be responsible for identifying and securing employers to create the employer based, STEM focused/aligned internships in all three SVETP career pathways.  Additionally, Growth Sector, a STEM Core Network leader, has experience with different strategies for accelerating students’ remedial math and English skills, and therefore they will select and hire nine Student Support Specialists (SSSs), one for each community college, beginning 2015-2016.  The SSS is an integral pivot point for the STEM Core model.  In partnership with Growth Sector, Transmosis will define and develop a detailed STEM Bootcamp and Internship Program for community college students, particularly in small to mid-size businesses and with start-ups.  The Transmosis program is designed to enhance their STEM skills and provide an internship to gain exposure and experience in the technology industry.  The goal is to build an effective, sustainable program that can be scaled across the Silicon Valley region over four years.
	 
Professional Development:  A significant outcome of SVETP will be state-of-the-art professional development for community college faculty and K-12 teachers.  TED-Ed’s mission is to amplify and share the ideas and voices of faculty, teachers and students around the world while supporting educators and students with video-based content, a web-based teaching tool, and professional development programming.  In particular, TED-Ed aims to collaborate with faculty and teachers to capture scalable, useful subject-based lessons that can be shared with the world for free. These lessons are produced with exceptional quality, crafted to inspire students to become more curious about all subject areas, and in particular, math, science and engineering topics.  
	 
And, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories (LLNL) is a critical partner in the SVETP career pathways project, an employer committed to this STEM foundation model, with paid internships, and as a professional development provider for faculty and teachers.  LLNL will have two specific program deliverables: 1) Advance Manufacturing Institute training for student/interns and teachers, operating as a boot camp with work-based learning (WBL) paid internships; and 2) management of the Advanced Manufacturing and STEM mobile learning laboratory that will provide WBL opportunities throughout the Silicon Valley region to over 2,000 K-12 and community college students. 
	 
Formal Evaluator:  UCLA HERI (Higher Education Research Institute) was engaged so an external evaluation team can provide a more formal evaluation infrastructure to examine our local "research questions" that emerge as we review student and faculty/teacher data, and evaluate barriers and accelerants to student progress in STEM core and career pathway programs.
By June 30, 2018 the grant funds will be expended and all education partners, other partners and employers have committed $19,488,112 in In-Kind Match to sustain SVETP with the STEM Core, career pathways and availability of paid internships through June 30, 2019.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the attached Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with 28 education and nonprofit partners, in the amount of $8,474,500,for the implementation of the Silicon Valley Engineering Tech Pathways (SVETP) July 1, 2015 – June 30, 2019.

On April 8, 2014 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with LPAS, Inc. for Professional Services which includes Design Development, Construction Documents, DSA Approval, Bid Documents, Contractor Pre-Qualification, Contractor Selection and Bidding, Construction Administration, and Close-Out/Post-Construction/Occupancy in the amount of $1,474,788  for the Physical Education Building  #122 at San Jose City College.
	 
Amendment No. 004 includes, providing design services for Owner requested changes.  LPAS, Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for changes that include additional work.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The item in this Amendment results in an addition to the contract of $12,000.
	 
         Original Contract Amount           $1,474,788
         Previous Approved Revisions     $  106,875
         This Revision No. 004                 $    12,000
                 
         Total Contract and Changes      $1,593,663

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.  
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 006 is the result of the District’s request for procurement and installation of shop equipment.  This purchase of Group-1 Furniture, Fixtures & Equipment (FF&E) of Vehicle Lifts, Exhaust Reels, added structural wall backing for FF&E items, additional compressed air piping to Vehicle Alignment Racks and electrical connections for relocated equipment from existing shops into the new Automotive Technology Building.  The change cost breakdown equates to 66% material and 34% installation.
	 
Including the Group-1 FF&E items in C. Overaa & Company’s contract will benefit the project because many of C. Overaa & Company’s subcontractors will be performing the required work, will eliminate the added time and expense of an additional procurement process, which would likely result in added cost due to the current bid market and will include the procurement and installation into C. Overaa & Company’s project warranty.  Legal counsel has reviewed and approved the above described approach, in addition, has affirmed that this level of cumulative change, now in excess of 10%, is allowable on a lease-leaseback contract.  Also per legal counsel, changing the funding source from owner furnished to contractor supplied does not require separate bidding due to the flexibility in the lease-leaseback delivery method since the scope had always been planned in the project.  The list of equipment remained a work in progress as the project started.
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposal has been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                 $11,347,704
Previous Approved Changes                            $     658,624
Change Order No. 006                                     $     704,244   
Total Contract and Changes                             $12,710,572
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $1,362,868, which equates to 12.01% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from the Group-1 FF&E budget established in the project budget.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 006 in the amount of $704,244 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building, Project #32111 - C. Overaa & Company Change Order No. 006
items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building, Project #32111 - C. Overaa & Company Change Order No. 006

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.  
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 007 includes the addition of pathway lighting along the Cedro/Autotech firelane, addition of temperature sensors, mechanical controls, weatherproof enclosures and structural supports for Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning systems to match District Standards, revisions to storefront window structural attachment details for added seismic stability, installation of tackable fabric wrapped panels in classrooms and a credit for exterior structural steel galvanizing with a substitution of high-performance paint for increased weather protection.
	 
C. Overaa & Company’s contract will benefit the project because many of C. Overaa & Company’s subcontractors will be performing the required work, will eliminate the added time and expense of an additional procurement process, which would likely result in added cost due to the current bid market and will include the procurement and installation into C. Overaa & Company’s project warranty.  Legal counsel has reviewed and approved the above described approach, in addition, has affirmed that this level of cumulative change, now in excess of 10%, is allowable on a lease-leaseback contract.  Also per legal counsel, changing the funding source from owner furnished to contractor supplied does not require separate bidding due to the flexibility in the lease-leaseback delivery method since the scope had always been planned in the project.  The list of equipment remained a work in progress as the project started.
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                 $11,347,704
Previous Approved Changes                            $  1,362,868
Change Order No. 007                                     $     194,947   
Total Contract and Changes                             $12,905,519
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $1,557,815, which equates to 13.73% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 007 in the amount of $194,947 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On June 9, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. in the amount of $917,500.00 to provide construction services for the Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 at San Jose City College.
		 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 002 is for design changes as well as changes resulting from unforeseen conditions. 
		 
R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda Details attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
		 
Original Contract Amount                        $     917,500.00
Previous Approved Changes                   $      19,555.00
Change Order No. 002                             $    106,600.00
Total Contract and Changes                    $ 1,043,655.00
		 
The net change to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $126,155.00 which equates to 13.75% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change and from project savings to date.
		 
		 
Pursuant to Public Contract Code sections 20118.4 and 20659 (applicable to community college districts), a contract may be increased or decreased after the bid is awarded due to changes that might arise during the course of the contract. These changes are limited to the bid limits or to 10 percent of the original contract price whichever is greater. These limits, according to the California Attorney General, "…appear to be inserted to ensure that substantial changes are not made which would, in effect, constitute the making of a new contract."[1] Furthermore, it is in the Attorney General’s view that “… change orders are appropriately contemplated where, during the performances of the contract, unforeseen matters are discovered which require some modification to complete the contract.” 73 Ops.Cal.Atty.Gen. 417 (1990).
		 
The purpose of Sections 20118.4 and 20659 is to allow some flexibility following the award of the bid, and to ensure that substantial changes are not made which would constitute the making of a new contract. In effect, the change order provisions allow districts to negotiate changes to a contract provided the contract is not materially altered by the change order to such an extent that it would create a new project or contract which should be bid separately.  Public bidding of the increased scope of Work would not have produced an advantage to the District, and would produce a net burden and distinct disadvantages to the District. Based on the foregoing, it would be incongruous, futile, and unavailing to publicly bid the increased scope of Work.  
		 
		 
This change order has undergone District legal counsel review for compliance with Public Contract Code. 
		 
The PCO’s presented within Change Order No. 002 were unforeseen matters that were discovered during construction and could not be anticipated prior to contract award. Details of the PCO’s can be viewed on the attached (Board Agenda - Details - CO No. 002 - RC Benson.doc). These changes were a necessary and integral part of the work under the contact and the taking of bids would delay the completion of contract, which were required to be completed during the Summer 2015 school break.
			 
[1] 73 Ops.Cal.Atty.Gen 417 (1990) footnote no. 3
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 002 in the amount of $106,600.00 to R.C. Benson & Sons Inc., for the Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 at San Jose City College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 – R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. - Change Order No. 002
items.item_text_raw: 5. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) Ironworkers Training Center Project #31126 – R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. - Change Order No. 002

items.item_details:
Evergreen Valley College is preparing to upgrade the network switches throughout the campus during this academic school year and next summer as part of the Network Infrastructure upgrade (Bond Project #32702). In preparation for this installation, EVC needs to purchase UPSs for the new switches. The UPSs protect the network switches from power surges and short power outages. This quote is based on a piggybackable WSCA contract that was Board approved on May 26, 2015 for UPSs for SJCC (Measure G Bond Programs Consent Agenda). The vendor is Transource Services Corp and the total cost for 149 UPSs is $123,496.87. 
	 
This quote does not include the costs to install the UPSs. The installation of the UPSs will be included in a future network switch installation contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of UPSs from Transource Services Corp for the Evergreen Valley College Network Switch Upgrade for a total cost of $123,496.87.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Uninterruptible Power Supplies (UPSs) for Evergreen Valley College Network Switch Upgrade
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Uninterruptible Power Supplies (UPSs) for Evergreen Valley College Network Switch Upgrade

items.item_details:
On May 26, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an order of 86 UPSs for the San Jose City College Network Switch Upgrade project (#31702). Before the purchase order was completed, it was determined that the number of UPSs needed was 63, not 86. This resulted in a revised quote of $100,166.74 and a reduced cost from the original Board Agenda item. 
	 
	 
Original Quote:       $146,163.33
Revised Quote:       $100,166.74
Deductive Change: -$45,996.59
	 
A purchase order was issued for the reduced number of UPSs at the reduced cost of $100,163.74.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Deductive Change Order No. 001 for ordering a decreased number of UPSs than originally requested on the May 26, 2015 Measure G Bond Programs Consent Agenda.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Uninterruptible Power Supplies (UPSs) for SJCC Network Switch Upgrade - Deductive Change Order No. 001
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Uninterruptible Power Supplies (UPSs) for SJCC Network Switch Upgrade - Deductive Change Order No. 001

items.item_details:
On May 12, 2015 the Board approved a contract for Dasher Technologies to install 334 Wireless Access Points (WAPs) at San Jose City College. A portion of the this contract included the network cabling installation for 195 of the WAPs. This deductive change order is to remove the installation of those 195 WAPs from the original ICA (BPO #12183) and results in a reduction of cost of $151,356.81.  
	 
Original Agreement Amount to install 334 WAPs and necessary cabling:        $172,037.10
Deductive amount for Change Order No. 001:                                                 -$151,356.81
New Agreement Amount to install 139 WAPS using existing cabling:               $20,680.29
	 
In the future, we will select another vendor to do the cabling installation for the 195 WAPs that require new cabling. The other 139 WAPs will be installed per the original ICA and attached quote.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 001 to the Phase 2 Wireless Installation Project at San Jose City College for a total cost reduction of $151,356.81.

The Adopted Budget is provided as an attachment to this item and also can be accessed on the Districtâs website.

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
Projects 39905:  Management and Related Costs and 39999: Election/Legal/EIR/ DO Labor and Related Costs are managed as separate projects in the Bond Program; however, the activities in these two projects benefit all active projects. By managing these activities as stand-alone projects during the year, the Districtâs bond management team is able to view and manage the budget and expenses that impact all projects in one location.  These costs are allowed to be distributed to projects for capitalization purposes.  The bond management team has determined that spreading the 39905: Management and Related Costs and 39999: Election/Legal/EIR/ DO Labor and Related Costs budget and associated expense to the active projects annually, as is allowed, provides a transparent view of the program.    
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 16 represents the transfer of budget, equal to the expense that will be spread to the individual projects through expense transfers prior to fiscal year close.  In this way, the budget balance remaining in 39905:  Management and Related Costs and 39999:Election/Legal/EIR/ DO Labor and Related Costs at the end of the fiscal year will reflect what remains for future years, and the projects will capture the expenses attributed to them.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 16 dated September 8, 2015.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented.

The District also expresses appreciation to the many faculty and staff members, who have created educational events in September and October that pay tribute to National Hispanic Heritage Month 2015.

items.item_details:
Staff will review the results of the 2015 Student Success Scorecard for San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College.  The Scorecard measures the success of students by tracking their progress along the pathway to completion of degrees, certificates, and transfer.  The outcomes tracked by the Student Success Scorecard are:
		 
Student Progress & Achievement Rate
Persistence Rate
30 Unit Achievement Rate
Basic Skills & ESL Progression Rate
Career & Technical Education Completion Rate
		 
		 
Each year, the California Community College Chancellor's Office will report on the status of these outcomes as a part of the State Chancellor's accountability reporting to the Governor.  The results for each college in the state are made public and can be used for comparison purposes.  Each college is required to share these data with the local Board of Trustees and inform the State Chancellor's office of the date of that report.
items.item_text: California Community Colleges Student Success Scorecard Board Engagement
items.item_text_raw: 4. California Community Colleges Student Success Scorecard Board Engagement

items.item_details: Beginning in September 2015, the Board will review the Global Ends Policy Dashboard once per quarter -- along with it's Quarterly Ends Policy Monitoring Report.  The last dashboard was reported in July 2015.  Since July 2015, there have been no changes in the Dashboard.  The Board can begin to see changes upon the next quarterly dashboard when new data for Institutional Effectiveness and College Experience come in.  The overall Global Ends Policy maintains a rating of "B".
items.item_text: Board Ends Policy Dashboard
items.item_text_raw: 5. Board Ends Policy Dashboard

items.item_details: The Board has scheduled regular updates to the Ends Policy Dashboard through quarterly Monitoring Reports.  At this meeting, the Board will hear a presentation about two ends policies: (1) College Readiness and (2) Student Success.  With this monitoring report the Board will have an opportunity to drill into the data related to these two policies with dis-aggregated data and trends. The goal of this presentation is to 1) share where District is in relation to the dashboard targets; 2) analyze the areas of strength and opportunities for improvement within the Ends Policies of Career Development and Transferability; and 3) set direction as to the areas of focus that should be the priority of the District as it relates to specified Ends Policies.  The Ends Policy Monitoring Report can support the District in making data-informed decisions and to establish priorities for the allocation fiscal and human resources to meet the goals measured in the Board Ends Policies.
items.item_text: Board Ends Policy Monitoring Report -- College Readiness and Student Success

Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
